Review for the "Acer Nitro V Gaming Laptop | Intel Core i5-13420H Processor | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4050".In my opinion the webcam is okay but quite noisy. The little microphones sound okay. Wish there was a hardware disable switch for the webcam and microphones.Gaming performance seems good for 1920x1080p Gaming at medium settings. In BFV while using performance mode I never dropped below 60FPS while at medium settings.Fan noise is a lot louder in performance mode, but if you switch to balanced mode then your FPS will suffer at the gain of decreased noise level.The screen is 144Hz which is great for non-intensive games and scrolling. It also seems pretty good with color accuracy.The CPU and GPU seem well matched performance wise. However, battery life is not great.There is only 8GB of RAM Which seemed in my testing to be fine if you're not doing too much at the same time. I only had a couple things open in the background while gaming and the RAM usage was at about 94%. So if you plan on doing more than one activity at the same time then I recommend getting 16GB of RAM.I thought the speakers sounded really good, and even without headphones I was able to track enemy positions. At max volume you will feel the explosions.The keyboard seems good to me. Not the best I have used, but it's good. For a laptop there is a lot of key travel, although there is some key wobble and the key corners sink too much for me. The backlight does not shine through the key letters.Overall, I think it can play games and give you a pretty good user experience. There was not too much bloatware, but I got rid of the McAfee before I did anything else. Trackpad is okay, screen is good, keyboard is mostly good, speakers are good. Internet connection with ethernet is fantastic.

reviewTitle: Good performance but very lacklustt control over the performance
reviewDescription: The setup was easy as it was a standard Windows setup, and the laptop itself feels solidly constructed as much as a plastic case laptop can feel. The keys feel alright, like typical scissor switch laptop keys and the screen is pretty good and clear looking.The primary focus of the laptop of course is gaming performance and in that front the laptop performs quite admirably. While plugged in with the included charger, the performance is on pair with a desktop 3050 but, however, when not plugged in and the max performance mode isn't able to be used, the performance is about 20 to 30 percent worse which is probably for the best though since when not plugged in this bad boy burns through the battery juice like nobodies business with the battery going down a percent basically every minute and a half while gaming.The battery life while not gaming is better but still not too great as the battery still goes down at an appreciable rate of about a percent every 2.5 minutes. Luckily, you can charge the laptop using usb c so you can charge the laptop using a power bank while you're not hooked up to a wall. The 65 watt usb c charging is enough to counteract the drain while gaming, but for some reason while charging this way the performance takes a leap down of about 20 percent, being even worse than when the laptop is on battery even though the laptop is being charged just not with the included charger.This brings me to the worse part about this laptop which is the horrendous amount of control that is given in terms of the performance and fan speed. The software is ass when it comes to fine tuning the power of the GPU and CPU as there are basically only 3 settings - eco, normal, and max. Similarly, the fan speeds have only around 7 speeds and the difference between each is too great so you can't get the noise level or heat of the GPU or CPU down to the amount that you actually want. As far as I know there is no way for any additional amount of control to be given since afterburner doesn't work as the GPU just throttles down to the standard performance setting.Still, the performance of the laptop is satisfactory, and it will run any games on the go as long as you adjust the settings to be lower since the laptop doesn't have too much power especially when not plugged into a wall and even more so when charging using a power bank using usb c which you may want to do whenever you want to use the laptop but also want to maintain the battery percentage but don't have an outlet to plug into.

The whole thing is made mostly of plastic, but doesn't look low-end at all. The design is very nice and relatively thin. The keyboard feels average, not suitable for typing, but fine for gaming, and it doesn't support RGB settings. But the touchpad is better than expected. The screen isn't too narrow, but it's not too wide either, which is nice. The screen is a 15-inch matte screen, does not support touch, and is of average quality. Because of its 1080 resolution, there's noticeable graininess on the 15-inch screen, but it supports a 144 refresh rate, which is great for gaming. The heat dissipation vent in the upper right corner is a bit awkward, as it blows hot air towards the display for a long time. I wonder if there will be permanent damage to the monitor later on.In performance mode, when running Cyberpunk 2077, the CPU performance can reach up to 20W, and the 4050 has a maximum performance of 75W. The average performance is about 56 frames, with a maximum of 85 frames and a minimum of 41 frames. The graphics card temperature was about 170 degrees Fahrenheit, but the keyboard position was only about 90 degrees Fahrenheit. , does not affect normal use at all, and the game is still smooth, because the monitor only supports up to 1080. Then use furmark to use 100% of both the CPU and graphics card. The maximum temperature is only about 170 degrees, the GPU power consumption is 75w, and the CPU is 20w. The fan is a bit noisy, but the cooling effect is good.Laptops in 2024 only have 8g of memory, which is indeed less, but you can add an extra piece of ddr5 memory. There are also a total of two SSD slots, m2 ssd PCIE x 4, and a 512G one is included. Equipped with a 57Wh battery, it can be used for about 4 hours under normal use. If used at full capacity, it can only last for one hour. There are also built-in speakers, the sound quality is very poor, and there is a popping sound when turned up to the maximum volume.This entry-level game console is actually equipped with Thunderbolt 4, which is very surprising. It can be used to connect external displays or transfer data quickly. It can also charge mobile phones, iPads, etc., but unfortunately it does not support powering laptop PDs. So you have to carry its bulk adapter.Best of all the price is $779. I think there are better options at this price point.

I chose this Acer Nitro for my wife as she basically does everything on her iPhone, however, not everything can be done on a smartphone, easily! I ran a benchmark of this Acer vs my Lenovo and this Acer is rated twice as good and good for gaming. I think an experienced gamer may hesitate with the i5, being more for a beginner. My Lenovo is i5 and after typically using i7, I noticed a big difference in response time when processing requests. I do have to say the Acer Nitro is much more responsive than my Lenova, though! As I am not a gamer, I can only go by my many years of using different laptops. The keyboard is standard qwerty, the included number pad is a must, for me, and the separate up/down/left/right arrows are very useful. Setup was quick and easy. Sleek case, modern. The 15" is screen is crisp and clean, making text easy to read. Images are excellent. Where we travel quite a bit, the easy of throwing into a back pack is great. the charger is by 3.5 mm or similar, but it also has a thunderbolt, type-c, port for additional charging options. My 65 w charger from the Lenovo would charge it, albeit slowly, and get a warning the charging is weak! The included Acer charger is 165 w, which explains the difference, but it is one less device of equipment we need to carry. In this day and age, not sure why they do not include a type-c charger. The other thing I miss on the Acer vs my other laptops, the touchscreen, I never realized how much I use a touchscreen until I'm on a laptop that excludes it.

Let me preface this by saying I am a Mac/Pc technician for over 20 years, so my Review may be a bit more harsh than Your average Person who just wants to play Fortnite or Call of Duty On the go, so keep that in mind!I have been a fan of the Acer nitro series since 2018 when I purchased my 7th Gen intel an515-51 outstanding price to performance! Flash forward to 2022 when I picked up a used  An515-54 which was just about better in every way  with a 9th Gen processor, Nvidia 1650, and ample room for storage!Now on To this Anv51-51 13th Gen i5,8 core, with a 4050 6gb!Outstanding Performance for an entry level Gaming system!Pros:13th gen 8 core(ish) ProcessorNvidia RTX 4050 6gb (75w)DDR5 5600mtWifi-6Gen 4 NVME SpeedThunderbolt 4144hz IPS ScreenLit keyboard (white)Easily upgradibleCons:(out of the box)Less Storage potential than previous Nitro SystemsONLY 512gb Gen4 NVMEONLY 8gb single channelScreen is the usual 45% Ntsc washed out dull displayOnly white Keyboard no RGB (I kinda liked the Red)4050 is a 75w mobile version (not full blown desktop 4050 performance)All of this to say that even out of the box this system is a Performance beast! High/ultra 1080p gaming at or above 60fps minimums (for the most part) The weakest part of all this is Ram and  storage! Why in 2024 are OEMs still ONLY putting single sticks of RAM in systems, further more for a Gaming system 512gb is simply NOT ENOUGH Storage for modern games ( example: Warzone is well over 200gb alone!) 512gb on a daily driver? No issue!I have upgraded to 16gb DDR5 5600, and the performance uplift in *most* games is 11% to 20% which is pretty significant . As for storage, I am disappointed we are limited to just 2 NVME slots, having a SATA drive with a much larger lower cost SSD or even Larger HDD was VERY handy on my previous Nitro. Time to price out another 2 or 4tb NVME drive. I have never had any issues with Acer devices! I don’t expect to with this unit!  I Do recommend it, just find it on sale so you can pick up extra storage and ram if needed!

The NVidia Geforce RTX 4050 in a gaming laptop at this price point is the real winner here.  Does the rest of this budget gaming laptop stack up?  As an entry level experience, yes.  This is not meant to be a powerhouse machine and the price reflects that.  The case is bare bones and only has the necessities; however, it does have room for expansion.  The num pad is crammed in, leaving less room for the rest of the keys.  The keyboard is backlit, but there’s no RGB or customization.  One particular annoyance I noticed with this keyboard is the num lock key has to be reset every boot up.This laptop can run all of the latest and greatest games so long as you aren’t attempting to max out the settings.  The harder it has to work, the less battery life you’ll have between charges and the louder it will get (and it gets LOUD).  The battery is the biggest issue here.  Even with basic use, it doesn’t last long.  I got about 4hrs out of it before it hit the 10% mark, and this was only from my testing various games and software.  I wasn’t playing any one single game for longer than twenty minutes, nor was I multi-tasking.  If you plan on using this in one place, it’s not really a big deal.  If you want something portable to travel and game, this probably isn’t for you.The screen is 1080p; not horrible, but not the best.  I do appreciate the matte surface, it cuts out a lot of glare.  The speakers are acceptable, but not something I would use on the regular.  A headset or a pair of nice external speakers is a must if you want a truly immersive experience.Overall, it’s not a bad deal.  It offers decent performance and has room to add a little more power if you want it.

reviewTitle: This laptop has become my backup computer
reviewDescription: I bought this laptop when Amazon gave it a monthly payment option at the time.My Desktop was constantly breaking down and I was trying to figure out what was the problem. While my desktop was in the shop (not knowingly the repair men there didn't do jack to figure out), I bought this laptop as a backup until my computer was fixed.Looking at the specs, 8GB RAM and only 250GB Storage isn't really enough to run and install most software (like games), so swapping out a 16 GB RAM and Adding a hard drive really helped it out exponentially. I only installed a few games that doesn't require too much GB's and they play well.That 144 Refresh rate though, I need to get me a monitor like that. Very smooth and fluid.At the time of this review, my desktop is fixed (by me replacing a faulty motherboard). I do want to keep this laptop as a backup in case something else happens.

I like everything about it. It has great graphics, great sound, and it's lightning fast, much faster than my previous I7 laptop. I'm only giving it 4 stars for no other reason that it is only 2 weeks old. I will up it to 5 stars when I've had it a while longer and it keeps up this level of performance.

reviewTitle: Buena Laptop para su precio, pesima bateria, touch pad y mouse
reviewDescription: Tengo la computadora 4 meses aproximadamente. Para el precio de compra las especificaciones son buenas, compre la version mas basica que comprende un i5, 250 gb nvme, 8 gb de ram y RTX 3050. Adicional a ello le compre 16 Gb de ram en dos Dim de marca Gskill y la cambie por el modulo que viene de fabrica. Los materiales de fabricacion son un 7.5/10, el touch pad es pesimo, lo peor es la camara de pesima calidad y los parlantes no suenan nada. Finalmente la bateria no dura si la utilizas para trabajar, en mi casa arquitectura, lo maximo que me a durado son 3 horas, el resto de tiempo debe estar 100% conectada.Los componentes son buenos pero si tiene puntos malos como los citados anteriormente.

reviewTitle: Great gaming PC but one part did not work
reviewDescription: The pc itself is beautifully detailed. I love the red and black. The only issue is the battery charger cord is not the correct fit. I bought another cord and it worked perfectly. That is important, the cord needs to fit properly. Other than that it was easy to setup and the keys glow in a red color. Perfect for gaming. My niece will love this birthday gift.

reviewTitle: Great Laptop but Check it all when it comes
reviewDescription: I'm definitely loving this laptop.I have a gaming rig with a Ryzen 5 3rd gen and XFX main card, and this laptop holds up with all the AAA titles I play on my big rig, BUT I can take it anywhere!The only reason this gets a 4 star is because it clearly states that there are supposed to be 2 stick (PCIE) SSD slots with a 2.5" HDD port to upgrade storage.When I popped this bugger open to add storage and RAM, low and behold I find it has only 1 stick SSD slots and a 2.5"Luckily I bought a 2.5" SSD instead of a stick (PCIE) since this thing clearly has a spot on the MB to have that extra PCIE slot but there is nothing there. So basically I get 1 PCIE and 1 2.5" HDD port instead of 2.Super disappointed, considering there is even a Nitro 5 sticker that says "Available slots: 2 SSD, 1 HDD"Unfortunately not true at all.....

I purchased this item and it works really well. I love the design of the screen and the keyboard. The only thing that I'm really disappointed with is the battery life, on the descriptions says up to 11 hours of battery life, the first weeks I had only 2 hours of battery and tan I had to plug the charger again. I called customer service and they told me that I needed to re-calibrate the battery. I was 1 day trying to complete the process and just gave me 2 more hours. I'll have to purchase another battery and change it because it was not was I was looking for, other than that it is perfect!

I've downloaded NOTHING to this laptop except for a few games totaling 30GB, yet I only have 68GB free out of 237GB total.170GB being used on...what? I just bought it. My son saved up for months to buy this computer. He was so excited when he finally had enough money! When it arrived, he plugged it in, eager to start gaming on his new laptop. Unfortunately, it never charged and it never turned out. So, we got a replacement. He was frustrated but willing to wait. The new one came quickly. However, the replacement had the exact same problem; it wouldn't turn on or charge. Now I have one very sad teenager on my hands and he is afraid to buy another laptop for fear of this happening again. We're not buying another Acer gaming laptop again.

Goodness. I ordered one of these laptops, only to have it arrive and find it has a defective charging port (I noticed it, and a representative at Best Buy confirmed), there was a bent prong in the port. I talked to an Amazon rep, and they sent me a replacement. Having gotten now a 2nd laptop with the same defect, I can confidently say to STAY AWAY from this. I was really looking forward to using this laptop, and even used my free trial of Amazon prime I'd been saving so I could get it over my vacation from work. Having gotten two defective laptops just killed that for me.

I received this laptop and pulled it right out the box only to learn that it does not work!! The repair for the laptop has been an absolute nightmare!! The laptop has a hard time staying connected to the internet with the ethernet cable. It's very laggy which makes this system very unstable for playing games. As soon as you start up the game the fan is going crazy and it blows out a lot of hot air underneath the left side of the laptop and it's loud.

reviewTitle: Model has known Charging / AC issues
reviewDescription: Bought 2 units, first did not work out of the box, Charging  / AC light was not lit, was unable to get power to the unit. Unit 2 worked for 3 hours, however when we tried to reconnect to the power cable to charge the laptop there was no power indicator.Contacted Acer, they advised that power plug was positional, I informed them that it was correct according to their own manual, The tech support person admitted that this model has known issue with it's AC/ Charging ability. I returned both units and will be purchasing a different brand at this point.
I bought this two years ago and guess what they lie. The battery lasts two hours if your lucky!!! It's also a built in battery...
Bueno para juegos 🎮.

Not sure why it wants you to rate it as a touch screen model when there's no function for it. However, after a few months with it I'm happy. I don't game much but I've played a few easy going games and have had no actual issues, and will be upgrading to 32GB of RAM just because. My biggest issue is that if you stay on a bright screen for a while, like Amazon for example, and then go to a website where you're using a dark mode, like I do on Discord, the ghost image can be seen. Also, when streaming shows/movies there's always a bright spot in the bottom left corner as if someone is home and forgot to turn the light off in a room. It's distracting.

I purchased the laptop for my daughter, this is what she said!“ Great brightness settings, decent colors but not fantastic for "hardcore" gamers or people wanting to get true colors for content creation/art. But for on the road projects and entertainment it is perfect, no complaints!It is not but it is very solid for what I need.Price to performance I give it 5/5, overall with personal preference if you could do decimals I'd give it 4.8/5.  Otherwise just 5/5”.

reviewTitle: Not as good as I hoped
reviewDescription: I expected so much more. Ready to trade it in already.

reviewTitle: The cpu heats itself to hell, 90degree temps
reviewDescription: So i got this and I don't really mess with these things but what pisses me off is haven't to fix every little thing. This laptop well really good for like a week or two until i noticed stupid frame drops, fortnite literately being unplayable and all. I then found the darn reason, I used Intel Xtu and saw the problem, overheating every darn time. I have a coolpad for this and my room is literally cold not blazin hot but yeah the cpu will hit 90 degrees! The gpu temps are always fine but the cpu sucks so hard so no wonder fortnite is unplayable. I found a couple options on reddit, they were to fix it myself by buying thermal paste, send it to acer to add shitty thermal paste so i can have this problem in a couple weeks again, or return and refund. Thing is, i got this well priced and the 3050 does what i need it for. I kid you not i play almost every game nearly max with optimizations done at that 144 fps and i have used programs to see my avg so yeah. Forza horizon 5 is the only thing I can't run at those frames cause the gpu has too few ram or whatever it uses, it's only 4gb. And yeah i did buy additional 8gb ram and 1tb ssd.So yeah, the games run well (overwatch, apex, definitely not fortnite, rainbow 6,).But it has heating issues, I'm personally going to exchange this and see if amazon does my a biggie by sending a unit before i send this one in cause i need a laptop, i know they did me this one time with another big purchase so shoutout to them.Edit: forgot to include that yes even with max fans the cpu thermal throttles. I know how to use nitrosence.

I don't do a lot of heavy gaming, so I wanted to buy a low-level gaming laptop because I knew it would do everything I needed to do. For context, the main games I play on my laptop are The Sims (with a ton of cc and a few mods), Stardew Valley (with a fair amount of mods), Terraria, and then basic in-browser games like tetris and whatever else when I'm truly bored. For the most part, this computer has handled running them all super well. Surprisingly, it has the most difficulty with the in-browser games, which tend to lag or drop frames. To be fair, I don't really know why Mahjongg 3D needs to be rendered in such intense detail anyway, but whatever.I don't have a lot of complaints about this computer. It does what I needed it to do. A couple of times I've had to reset my settings because my built-in microphone will randomly turn itself completely off. Also, sometimes, when I'm switching tabs or something, my screen will just go black for a second or two. That's the biggest complaint. If I needed to use this machine to play Valorant or Fortnite or whatever, a few seconds of a black screen could cost me the game. However, I'm still satisfied with all that I'm able to do using this computer, especially considering the price. I've been using the same old computer for ages because every subsequent computer has just been too slow for me. I'm happy to say that this is not the case with this computer, and as long as it runs decently and lets me play The Sims and watch Netflix, I probably will stay pretty happy.

reviewTitle: good for what it needs to be
reviewDescription: Model: Acer Nitro 5 AN515-55-53E5 -Upgrade & Linux infoMy first order of this came DOA. It happens sometimes. The replacement came quickly. this has 2x M.2 NVME slots. I added a Samsung 980 1TB (no need to buy an extra screw). I also added another 8GB ram Crucial RAM 8GB DDR4 2666 MHz CL19 Laptop Memory. By adding things myself it made it cheaper than buying a more expensive unit. Yes it is only an I5 but I do not need a lot. I does exactly what I need and well. Battery life is about 2 or 3 hours depending on what youre doing. I always expect horrible battery life so Im not shocked. the keys feel nice. red backlit only (Meh) but the intensity can be decreased or increased via the keys in Linux & Windows.LINUX - load Windows into safe mode, go into bios, ctrl + S will show the add the option to allow you to change the mode to AHCI. reboot to windows and take it back out of safe mode. Install linux as normal. For this unit I install ElementaryOS with zero issues and left windows on the factory NVME. Everything works as expected including the microphone and camera. I would recommend a mouse & mousepad but thats your call.  If you are nervous about installing linux or it is your first time, remove the 256GB nvme, install linux on the added drive, replace 256GB, update grub [ sudo update-grub].  Hope this helps someone out there. I know the open source community and Linux always look for someone who has run gauntlet to see how it works. reviewTitle: Arrived today, running quick and smooth so far
reviewDescription: I see a lot of people complaining about the disk space and yeah, it’s low for a gaming laptop but I just got me a 1tb m.2 ssd for $126 so I’m not complaining. Even with 8gb Ram it seems to run smooth and work well also (though I am upgrading to 32gb). I can’t comment on the gaming bc I can’t install a real game until my ssd upgrade comes in but I’m hopeful and I’m happy thus far. It is important to note that to charge you have to push the cable in kinda hard until you hear the click sound, otherwise it doesn’t charge. It took me a few minutes to figure that out. Also, not a lot of bloatware installed so that’s good too; it’s unnecessary to use Norton when you have Windows Defender so I’d uninstall it along with Dropbox. Laptop isn’t very heavy and to keep it that way I’m opting to not use the HDD bay and instead just use m.2 ssd instead. This seems like a quality product so far so hopefully it lasts as long as my last Asus laptop did (6+yrs & still going). Wish a Blu-ray drive was included but not a deal breaker as you can buy an external slim one for around $100. Highly recommend this system so far, just know you’re going to need to upgrade the storage immediately before playing storage heavy games like WoW, COD, etc hence 4/5 stars.edit 3/5/22: I've had this awhile now & no issues at all still. I really like this laptop.

reviewTitle: Fantastic overall though some things to keep in mind/be aware of
reviewDescription: So I've had my Acer for almost a year now and here are my thoughts, struggles, FYIs for those thinking on getting one.First big thing is RAM 8gb is a very small amount and if you're planning on any sort of heavy gaming beyond some old titles or mmo you'll want to upgrade it (great thing is though that it's easy enough to swap out).Second is battery when I was still deciding on buying or not there was a few reviews mentioning a possible battery issue where it it will start losing its charge and having to swap it and sure enough after a few months I saw my battery slowly but surely losing its charge and decided to order a replacement. Now as I was waiting for it I lost power for some hours mid gaming and chose to just run the battery out until it came back after draining it and the power got back on for charging the battery issue was gone which while great was a bit frustrating having to go through a return for the replacement battery.Lastly temperature it can get fairly warm so I'd recommend getting a cooling pad if anything for longevity especially if you're like me and plan on using it for years to come.Outside of those couple things it's been perfect for me especially for an under 1k laptop.

reviewTitle: If you can swing it, get the Legion 5 instead.
reviewDescription: In the "almost touching four figures" range, there are a lot of surprisingly good gaming laptops coming onto the market from different manufacturers. Assuming each one was available, you'd be spoiled for choice this summer. Decent processors, nice midrange RTX GPU's, and at least a certain degree of expandability should be expected.Acer's Nitro 5 is... well, not great. Personally, when I think Acer, I think "budget". And there's nothing wrong with budget systems and components. I'm quick to recommend Acer to people on a tight budget who are looking for entry-level laptops. Their stuff isn't top-tier, but is usually fine for what you pay. Few of us have infinite dollars to spend on computers. Though Acer tends to make their products *feel* like they're not quite as good as everything else, and the Nitro 5 is no exception here.Case in point: at the time of this writing, another hundred bucks or so gets you the. And for that hundred dollars, you get build quality that makes the Nitro feel kind of flimsy, you get a processor that absolutely trounces the comparatively anemic i5 10300H, twice the RAM, twice the storage space, an ARGB keyboard, and a faster refresh rate on the display.All that, for a hundred bucks. Give or take.So, is that a testament to Lenovo giving you an incredible value, or Acer not being up to par? Yes.Having both systems side-by-side, it highlights so many places where Acer could have delivered, but cheaped out. When you delve into what you're getting with the Nitro 5, everything about it feels like you took the cheapest thing on the shelf. From the very beginning, you need to dedicate nearly an hour out of the box just for Windows updates that Acer didn't add to their shipping image. And not because of a slow connection (I was hitting in the neighborhood of 800 megabits over 802.11ax) but you can feel how constricted the system really is with that i5 and only 8 gigs to work with.Once you've got your Windows updates set, you have to navigate the sea of bloatware that Acer loaded the Nitro 5 up with. No, I don't want Express VPN. No, I don't want Dropbox. No, I don't want your weird app store. No, I don't want your... whatever this password manager thing is that I've never heard of. No, I don't want... And it hits you that while you'd wading through all of this junk, Acer thought it would be good to put their system update software other than in the Acer folder. It's kind of a head scratcher.All the while, the bottom of the laptop gets scorching hot. Yeah, a gaming laptop without a great vapor chamber is going to get toasty, but again, it's one of those areas where Lenovo figured out how to make efficient heat pipes that make the Legion 5 bearable. Why didn't Acer?So I moved on. Let's get 3DMark and PCMark on here, and see how it compares. And even that produced a "Go home, Acer. You're drunk." kind of emotion. Load up 3DMark, and it says "Hey, you've got an i5, and I see this RTX 3050 over here..." and then it barfs at the end saying that it couldn't quite figure out what you have. I installed official GeForce drivers, uninstalled and reinstalled 3DMark, and still got the same "This isn't official because reasons." message. But don't take my word for it. Check out the pictures I've attached.So the results, while not "official" tell a pretty interesting story about what a hundred bucks more gets you. As you can see, these are the Acer Nitro 5 against the Lenovo Legion 5. While 3DMark is calling the GPU "Generic VGA", you can see for yourself that the specs are correct for a 3050 dGPU and are too high to be the iGPU from the i5. But they're also 1618 apart.For perspective's sake: the difference between the Nitro 5 and the Legion 5 is 100 points greater than the difference between the Legion 5 and my desktop Ryzen 9 5900X with an RTX 3080 GPU. And again, you can see that the dGPU is running at full frequency. Even if you're thinking "Oh, this dude is a total Lenovo shill, and the results don't have approved drivers, and I'm an internet detective and blah, blah, blah..." look at the CPU scores. There's no CPU driver. And it isn't like Acer or Lenovo are like "Yeah, go hog wild with settings for undervolting and underclocking in our expansive BIOS features" on either system.In my review of the Legion 5, I took it apart and ran PC Mark, and dug deeper into it because I couldn't believe how much power you were getting for the price. But with the Nitro 5, I didn't see much point. The moment you try to slap more RAM into it, you're at the same price point. It would cost you more to bring just the RAM and NVMe drive to the same specs as the Legion 5, and you'd still have a slower computer with a slower refresh rate, worse warranty, inferior build quality, middling keyboard, and terrible heat management.

reviewTitle: USB ports all died within 1 day of purchase. Turns out to be a common problem.
reviewDescription: I bought this laptop intending to make it dual-boot into Windows and Linux. To do that I had to get it to boot from a USB stick and let me repartition it and install a new OS.Right away I found issues. Nowhere in the limited documentation that came with the laptop do they tell you how to get into the bios. I had to google that. Then the BIOS itself was total crap. I had to jump through many hoops to even get it to consider booting from another drive. Around that time the USB ports started failing, one by one (Windows would *sometimes* see a USB drive, but could never read them. The BIOS couldn't even see them).I did everything I reasonably could. I made sure I had the latest version of the BIOS and the latest version of all relevant drivers and checked Acer Support for information. Nothing. This thing is being returned.

reviewTitle: ATTENTION: YOUR ACER5 NITRO NOT POWERING ON OR CHARGING? Push it in Then Push it a second Time!
reviewDescription: ATTENTION IF YOU CANT POWER ACER NITRO 5 ON READ THISI just got my Acer5 today 6/5/2022 so I can't say much about it yet in regards to experience, however I can tell you how it was delivered, I didn't like the delivery method at all. When the package arrived the box was hanging open with some garbage quality amazon tape barely holding it closed, the box it was in for shipping was WAY larger than it needed to be, rectangular wide almost 75% bigger than my laptopsactual box and had no filler to keep it from moving, im surprised it was still in the delivery box at all.None the less I tried to test the laptop and it wouldnt turn on I figured it was dead as I tested it in my car with an outlet in my car at work, fine whatever. I bring it back home (just go with it) and I try an actual wall outlet when I get off work, doesn't work just like the car. At this point i'm thinking, I know how computers work this is stupid and defective and I'm frustrated. I got all the way through starting theprocess of sending it back on amazon when I googled one last time for answers and this worked for me.TLDR Answer: Plug the laptop in, it will feel like its in but its not, make sure its plugged in with the plug facing sideways in the socket, then press down HARDER, and you will hear a click, basically you push it into th slot once and then push it a second time to get it in. It's some kind of feature and it made me think my laptop was bonked up. I hope this helps people, I know I was FRUSTRATED, otherwiseseems like a decent laptop so far.Edit: It seems this has helped 50 people thats cool. Would be kinda cool to see what people have to say. If you'd like to direct thankyou messages feel free to email "deudomufo@gmail.com" im moderately enthused to hear how it's helping out.P.S. laptop is still working great, but it does run into some issues as a video editing laptop in after effects. The software eventually freezes permanently and you have to close it. Which is a shame because the GPU should be great for it.. I believe it may just need another ram stick, the laptop is expandable.

reviewTitle: For the price, a solid laptop
reviewDescription: For the price, this is a solid laptop to be used for basic gaming. However, I would say that this laptop is not really great at anything it does. The SSD is too small for a lot of games to be installed, but it does have an extra SSD and HDD slot, so you can easily upgrade (which I did after about a month). The RAM is also lacking, but another easy upgrade to make. Another negative is the build quality. The laptop feels cheap and plasticy (which I don't think is a word), but for the price that you pay it can be expected. The battery life for basic tasks, like writing, internet research, and light movie watching is pretty terrible. At most I get 3-4 hours. But for gaming, you wouldn't use it off the charger anyways so its a mute point if you plan on using the laptop for its stated purpose.Now for some positives. The display itself is really nice. Games look great as well as movies and it has a really nice refresh rate. I actually enjoy the typing experience of the keyboard.For games, this laptop plays Farming Simulator perfectly on maxed settings. Call of Duty Modern Warfare 2 can be played at slightly less than max settings as long as you are using it off the laptop screen. If you are using an external monitor, depending on the size of the monitor you might run into a little bit of trouble. I have a 49" monitor and when I tried plugging the laptop into it wasn't able to maintain the same quality and performance.Overall, I would say that if you are looking for a cheap gaming laptop to do some light gaming on the road then this is a good laptop for that. If you want a gaming laptop and one you can do work on the coach with, this isn't it. If you want hardcore gaming, this also isn't. For the price though, I would say that its a solid laptop just don't expect to do everything you want at max settings.

I have had this laptop for over a year now. It's just.. okay. The screen is big and high refresh rate is always nice. As expected, battery life is not that amazing, but that's a trademark of all gaming laptops. It's slow on battery, but not bad once plugged into a wall. The audio jack has this awful whining from electronic noise, but I was able to fix it by using a USB c to audio jack on the other side. keyboard's decent, touchpad is alright. Seems like a great gift  for a younger person who wants a "gaming laptop" without blowing out your bank. Having an ethernet port is great, as it allows me to troubleshoot networks more easily. 3/5 Gaming laptop. As stated it's a good middle of the road laptop. It can be quite cumbersome to use as an actual laptop is some cases though, because of its size. I was able to run VR on it decently okay as well. VRchat has some issues during large events, but for average use or Beatsaber use it'll work just fine.

reviewTitle: Incredibly solid gaming laptop for the price, with some flaws.
reviewDescription: Just to cut to it, this specific model of the Nitro 5 is incredibly a solid all-around; from the lots of room to expand storage/RAM, great keyboard, good cooling, etc.. The performance is great as well as it can play most modern games at 1080 ultra settings at great FPS.The negatives for me come in two-fold: the display and battery life.1. The display being 144hz and IPS is great and all, but the actual quality of it is below mediocre. While backlight bleed is expected for an IPS panel, it's weirdly uneven and discolored. Also, I'm not sure if it's a defect with my specific device, but the display can't produce the color red accurately (it's more orangish) and overall things look a bit flat and there's no way to actually fix it besides finding your own ICC file. And even then you might as well use an external monitor.2. The battery life is terrible. Even on powersaving mode the laptop barely lasts 5 hours, and that's just doing basic internet browsing. I'm honestly considering not being bothered with it and just removing the battery entirely.

I'm generally very pleased by this laptop but there are a few issues worth mentioning:- The trackpad is weirdly offset to the left for some reason instead of being in the center of the frame. This means that whenever I have my left hand on WASD, the base of my thumb rests on the corner of the trackpad which then slightly adjusts the mouse whenever I have to press space or alt. I don't play any games that would require this degree of precise aiming (like FPS, because I suck at them) but I imagine it would be infuriating if I did.- When I'm alt-tabbing from a graphics-intensive game like dark souls 3 to a different program, the screen flashes black for a second. Not really a major issue but it was slightly worrying at first.Aside from that, performance is great, can't really speak to the battery life since I've yet to use it while unplugged, but it's a powerful machine and I haven't had any issues with performance.

I like the performance allowing you to change the graphics settings of a game on the GeForce Experience app.Pros: Good Performance, easy to use and navigate, High GraphicsCons: Always having to discharge and recharge it for performance and battery multiple times, Poor Battery Life,
It’s a good laptop overall but there seems to be problems with it every now and then, for example the laptop freezes up every now and then but not so often

Good sub-$1000 gaming laptops are hard to find, but The Nitro 5 gives great value without breaking the bank.  The 10th Gen Core i5 processor is 2 generations old at this point, but it has plenty of power to run pretty much all modern games at a decent setting.  The Nvidia RTX 3050 graphics processor is an entry level to the new Ray-Tracing sexiness that's the next big thing in graphics.  On newer games you probably won't be able to get past the 60fps barrier at 1080p with the settings cranked, but dialing the details down a bit will give you better rates. The display is rated for 1080p and 144hz, and while it's not the brightest or most vibrant screen out there, it's fine for this price point.  There is also a (full size) HDMI out, but I have not had occasion to connect this to an external monitor yet.  The cooling fans do a good job of keeping this machine within temp specs... but do note they can get pretty loud under load (honestly that's almost inevitable on a gaming laptop, it's hard to keep things cool in such a small box. Anyone who games on a laptop should invest in a good headset IMHO.)I have opened this computer up to install a few upgrades (more on that below) and I will say I'm pretty impressed with the build quality for a computer in this segment.  The components are reputable makes rather than mystery off-brands (WD for the SSD, looks like Micron on the single 8gb RAM stick.) All the panels fit together nice and go back together easily after disassembly, making upgrades something you don't have to dread.Speaking of those upgrades... for a computer at this price point you have to live with a few compromises and here is where they may be found.  The storage this model comes with is a paltry 256gb m.2 drive... If you do plan on gaming on the Nitro, either be ready to upgrade this quickly or learn to love delete-ing and re-installing games and apps constantly.  Fortunately, there is a second un-used m.2 PCIe slot on the motherboard to accommodate an upgrade (this processor and motherboard supports PCIe up to gen-3 speeds.) There is also an open 2.5 inch bay for an SSD. Memory-wise, this unit comes with a single 8gb DDR4 SODIMM RAM stick installed.  This should be fine for most gaming- if you don't run big apps in the background-  but since this has two slots total for an upgrade I removed it and installed 2 8gb sticks of Kingston FURY Impact DDR4 RAM,  just for a bit of extra headroom (the max speed the i5 10300H will operate memory at is 2933 Mhz, so it's not worth it to spend more on faster RAM.)All in all, this is a fine machine for someone who's interested in a good no-fuss entryway into PC gaming, or a seasoned gamer who wants an inexpensive but capable machine to go mobile with. Highly Recommended!

This is very much a highly modifiable and budget friendly starter PC. As soon as you look at the hardware you know there are going to be bottleneck points if you want to actually use this for more than 1 modern program. I immediately put it a Predator SSD and upgraded the RAM to 32 bit @ 3200 MHz (two RAM sticks at 16 is going to benefit more than a single 32) which skyrocketed the CPU performance. Every upgrade video you will see show a bunch of adapters that you don't need. There are two (2) M2 ports you can easily access removing the bottom; one hosts the original Hard Drive and the second I put the new SSD drive in, I then followed the Hard Drive copy process on their website and within 10 minutes I was done. It also opened up the bottleneck in the system and allowed games to appropriately use the GPU.Now, the GPU is just midgrade but you get what you pay for. You're not going to play Battlefront / COD at 1080p by any means without a lot of lag, but after just the two upgrades every game so far it flawless at 720p. I could have also lowered the refresh rate from 144 Hz and gotten the responsive 1080p at the cost of smoothing. You can plug in an HDMI-ported high refresh display that bypasses the graphics bottleneck but you got a laptop for a reason and the GPU can still only handle so much.Overall, this is my first time getting a dedicated gaming PC and I'm extremely happy with not only how well it performs but how well laid out it is to modify/upgrade. I would recommend it to people starting out and don't have a high graphics demand.
